thread.title: Our recommendations from Orleans to St. Tammany: Editorial
thread.title_full: Our recommendations from Orleans to St. Tammany: Editorial | NOLA.com

author: The Editorial Board, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: Our recommendations from Orleans to St. Tammany: Editorial
text:
The NOLA.com | Times-Picayune editorial board makes the following recommendations for the Saturday (Oct. 24) ballot . For a full list of our recommendations, go here . To see recommendations by precinct, go here.
ORLEANS PARISH
SCHOOL BOARD, 1 ST DISTRICT
Keith Barney
Mr. Barney has 25 years of experience as a teacher and school administrator. He currently is a special education/language arts teacher at Arthur Ashe Charter School. He also is president of the board at Mary Coghill Charter School.
ST. BERNARD PARISH
PRESIDENT
No recommendation
ST. CHARLES PARISH
PRESIDENT
Larry Cochran or
John Cornwell
Mr. Cochran is a seasoned elected official who has helped guide the Parish Council, currently as chairman. He is a two-term district councilman from St. Rose and has served the district ably as a representative and as a volunteer firefighter.
Mr. Cornwell, a retired law enforcement officer with the State Police and St. Charles Parish Sheriff's Office, is also a former district governor for the Rotary Club. He's civic-minded and has experience with contract negotiations and creating policies.
ST. JOHN THE BAPTIST PARISH
PRESIDENT
Natalie Robottom
Ms. Robottom is knowledgeable about local and state government and has gained valuable experience in her first term. Her administration has overseen $53 million in infrastructure improvements and succeeded in getting approval by the Corps of Engineers for a crucial federal storm protection levee.
ASSESSOR
Kevin Prudhomme
Mr. Prudhomme is a deputy assessor in the office who would bring years of experience with the assessment process and the law.
SHERIFF
Mike Tregre
Sheriff Tregre has served the parish well in his first term. He is a 27-year veteran of law enforcement who worked his way up the ranks. He understands the challenges of the parish and the department and is focused on executing a plan to reduce crime.
ST. TAMMANY PARISH
PRESIDENT
Pat Brister
Ms. Brister has extensive experience in government, first as a Parish Council member for eight years and now as parish president. She has energized the economic development process and attracted major new investment in the past four years. She served as state Republican Party chairwoman 2000-04.
SHERIFF
Jack Strain
Sheriff Strain, who has led the Sheriff's Office since 1996, runs a highly effective agency. Despite a population boom, crime has decreased under his watch. His department also has a strong record for solving crimes.
ASSESSOR
Louis Fitzmorris
Mr. Fitzmorris has stabilized the office and improved technology since he took office in 2013. He has removed hundreds of ineligible homestead and land use exemptions from the tax rolls and eliminated take-home cars.
